{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3127295,"name":"Aidan Mundy","username":"Aidan-Mundy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidan-mundy/{size}/177044_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T05:23:49.924Z","cooked":"

Our robot design includes a fairly hefty arm that will likely be driven by dual 125:1 MAX Planetary gearboxes with subsequent 3:1 or 4:1 chain reductions.

Where in the system would a WCP Friction Brake best fit?

There are two obvious options in my mind, but looking for thoughts and alternatives:

  • Before the MAX Planetary
    • Benefits: Higher reduction after the brake
    • Problems: No obvious way to add the brake here.
      • Is there a good way to do hex input for the MAX Planetary?
  • After the MAX Planetary, before the chain reduction
    • Benefits: Easier to affix because of the hex shaft output
    • Problems: Low reduction after the brake
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T05:34:35.821Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":432,"reads":521,"readers_count":520,"score":2264.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Aidan Mundy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5113A, 87A"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/1","custom_user_title":"5113A, 87A","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3127317,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T06:01:28.280Z","cooked":"

More justification for the brake after the planetary is also backlash, ideally after the chain reductions.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T06:01:28.280Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":492,"readers_count":491,"score":118.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/2","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127325,"name":"Aidan Mundy","username":"Aidan-Mundy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidan-mundy/{size}/177044_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T06:32:22.723Z","cooked":"

The WCP guide for the brake reccomends installing it at the first stage of your reduction and specifically says it isn’t intended for 1:1 installation (like after the chain reduction).

I suspect it won’t be strong enough after the chain reduction, which is why I didn’t list that as an option in the OP.

EDIT: Definitely not strong enough. Nominal rating is 1.5 lb-ft

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T06:45:42.736Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":460,"readers_count":459,"score":152.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Aidan Mundy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5113A, 87A"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/3","custom_user_title":"5113A, 87A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127329,"name":"R.C.","username":"R.C","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/r.c/{size}/264998_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T06:47:15.553Z","cooked":"

Aiden,

I definitely recommend putting this on the input or as close to the motor as possible. We’ve used this a few times directly on the motor via a 1/2" hex adapter with greyt results. It will work poorly if used on the end of a 125:1 gearbox.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T06:47:15.553Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":416,"readers_count":415,"score":148.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"R.C.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":30018,"username":"Aidan-Mundy","name":"Aidan Mundy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidan-mundy/{size}/177044_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9979,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127335,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T06:59:56.170Z","cooked":"

With most loads in FRC at 125:1 you can just stall the motor for a short period. Check out the locked rotor stall test at motors.vex.com. If you’re doing dual motors guaranteed you’ll be cooking (in performance, not motors).

How about a disc brake? During my research I noticed 5803 used one (2018 I think).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T07:04:01.486Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":371,"readers_count":370,"score":84.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"chrisrin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127346,"name":"Aidan Mundy","username":"Aidan-Mundy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidan-mundy/{size}/177044_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T07:38:30.155Z","cooked":"
Andrew_L:

With most loads in FRC at 125:1 you can just stall the motor for a short period.

With an extra 4:1 at the end… so more like 500:1. TBH, should be fine… I do like to hedge my bets though, especially with the stowed position being up in the air.

chrisrin:

How about a disc brake?

Trying to avoid custom solutions as much as possible. Limited machining capabilities ATM. It’s definitely been discussed, but I’m not sure how we’d go about implementing it.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T07:38:30.155Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":357,"readers_count":356,"score":86.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Aidan Mundy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5113A, 87A"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/7","custom_user_title":"5113A, 87A","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127353,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T08:23:52.139Z","cooked":"

If you can run a poorly-tuned PID loop (or just P, really) and stay under 5% of the motor stall current when holding the arm out in place, you will have no issues controlling it. If you need more speed, add more motors and reduce the gear ratio. Going up to 10% is possible very slightly less trivially - you might actually need I and D. That’s just my conservative rules of thumb for arm gearing. Unless your arm is truly massive, 2 NEOs or Falcons will have no issues driving things pretty fast that those ratios. A brake in this application probably won’t help you much compared to spending that integration time on programming.

Above 10% depends on how well you run your feedforwards and programming in general. Outside the range of my thumb.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T08:24:43.558Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":188.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127382,"name":"Jon Stratis","username":"Jon_Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T12:43:19.574Z","cooked":"
Aidan-Mundy:

Trying to avoid custom solutions as much as possible. Limited machining capabilities ATM. It’s definitely been discussed, but I’m not sure how we’d go about implementing it.

We’ve used this a couple of different times:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B07458MXNB?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title

The hole pattern is in metric, but close enough to a standard hub (AM hex hubs at the time for us) to work just fine. A couple of short spacers to bolt the calipers into a 2x1 near the axle, put the hub on the axel so it lines up, and run the cable to a pneumatic piston elsewhere on the robot. We did it all with hand tools successfully for destination deep space! If I remember to, I can grab a nice picture at our meeting this evening.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T12:43:19.574Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":288,"readers_count":287,"score":157.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Jon Stratis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B07458MXNB?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":27}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/9","custom_user_title":"FRC 2177 Mentor, LRI, MN RPC","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127415,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T14:55:48.322Z","cooked":"

oops, missed this was a specific part and just thought it was a generic disc break.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T14:55:48.322Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":53.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":30018,"username":"Aidan-Mundy","name":"Aidan Mundy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aidan-mundy/{size}/177044_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/10","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127431,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T15:15:38.887Z","cooked":"

EagleForce has used these very effectively in previous years. With just a little engineering it can be operated by a pneumatic cylinder and a little code.
My Rookie team will likely be using one this year.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2023-01-16T15:15:38.887Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":233,"readers_count":232,"score":46.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":423364,"topic_slug":"wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary","display_username":"billbo911","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7968,"username":"Jon_Stratis","name":"Jon Stratis","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_stratis/{size}/2663_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-friction-brake-with-maxplanetary/423364/11","custom_user_title":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3127537,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-16T18:35:55.047Z","cooked":"
Aidan-Mundy:

stowed position being up in the air

Even better, that’s when your arm experiences lower torque load from gravity! At full vertical, your arm’s weight is just a linear force on the pivot point (assuming it’s in-line with your arm). There’s no horizontal distance off the pivot point to create a torque. Your arm creates the greatest torque at full horizontal, when the lever arm of the COG is the greatest distance away from the pivot point. The torque your arm induces on the system is affected by the cosine of the angle it is above the horizontal plane.

As an example, an arm with a weight of 8 lbs and a COG 15 inches from the pivot point is going to experience a max torque of 15in • 8 lbs = 120 in•lbs when the lever arm is fully horizontal. However, when the lever arm is 30° above horizontal, only a fraction of the torque is induced, so the amount of torque induced on the system is equal to 15in • 8 lbs • cos(30) = 103.9 in•lbs.

120 in•lbs of torque vs. 103.9 in•lbs of torque. Not necessarily a huge difference, but one worth considering. It’s not a linear scale either, as defined by that cosine.

Tl;Dr: understanding your use cases can help remove constraints in your robot design. If you’re never stalling your motors closer than 30° off the horizontal (or whatever angle you choose), then that’s the typical load situation you can design for. Use the locked rotor stall test at motors.vex.com and do the math on your stall voltage to see how long you can stall a motor for and at what voltage for your use case. Or just use the safe-stall solver on my design calculator: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pD2lm0G4NEgJfX5yduQPMq37ILjBh6mkQRrLHxopsuE/copy?usp=drivesdk (note: pure mathematical models for safe stall extremes are to be used as guidelines for factors of safety, not for guaranteed successful data points to base your design around).

Aside: I use the term lever arm to refer to the distance between your pivot point and your arm’s center of gravity (COG). The angle of your lever arm is not always the same as the angle of your arm. If your arm has some weight offset from the arm, it likely will affect the location of the center of gravity, which in turn will affect the angle of the lever arm. This is why I will design a rotational system first before figuring out what gear ratio I need for it.

I wonder what the current draw is for that, the page doesn’t appear to specify max draw. Regardless, I would expect you would want to use the REV Servo Power Module to power it. It may work, you’d have to get it all and test it!

Keep in mind that FRC Servos can only be powered from the RoboRio or Rev Servo Power Module (R505), so you’re limited to 6V - none of those provides the higher 8.4V you need for the max torque listed on that page.

WOW! That over 100lb of pull on that brake!
We typically only used just under 50lb and it always held fine. Was there a reason you needed that much force?
No kill like overkill.
